title: Swedish News Briefing — 14 February 2026
script:
Good morning. Here's your Swedish news briefing for Sweden today, Saturday the 14th of February.

Let's start with some important policy news. Sweden is investing billions in new naval frigates to strengthen its position against Russia. Defence Minister Pål Jonson says the purchase sends a clear signal that Sweden is ready to defend its territory. The deal could cost tens of billions of krona, but these ships will become a key part of Sweden's military capability in the Baltic Sea region.

On the political front, there's been some controversy around immigration enforcement. Teen deportations have sparked significant debate, with concerns being raised about how authorities are handling cases involving refugee children. Some voices are questioning whether current practices align with Swedish values, particularly regarding how family connections are being assessed.

In economic news, electricity prices remain a major concern for Swedish households. One homeowner we've heard from has taken matters into his own hands, optimising his heating system to reduce consumption and push back against rising costs. He says he's tired of sending money to electricity companies without getting value in return. If you're struggling with your bills, there are solutions available — energy audits and system upgrades can make a real difference.

There's also been attention on job-seeking in the age of artificial intelligence. As more companies use AI to filter applications, job hunters need to know the tricks to avoid being automatically sorted out. The advice is straightforward: tailor your applications, use relevant keywords, and make sure you're not getting lost in the algorithmic shuffle.

On a lighter note, sexual harassment on secondhand shopping platforms is becoming a concern. Young people selling clothes on apps like Vinted have reported receiving inappropriate messages. The Minister for Gender Equality is pushing for stricter requirements on digital platforms to protect users better — this is clearly an issue that needs addressing.

Finally, if you're looking for something to do this weekend, the Berlin Film Festival is underway, and several Swedish cultural events are happening. Swedish actor Gustav Lindh is walking the red carpet for a new apocalyptic western film. Back home, Melodifestivalen — Sweden's song competition — continues with its third heat this weekend.

That's your briefing for today. For more details on any of these stories, visit SVT Nyheter or Dagens Nyheter online. Stay informed, stay safe, and we'll be back tomorrow with more Swedish news. Have a good weekend.

stories.headline: New frigates to become Sweden's military power against Russia
stories.summary: Sweden is purchasing new naval frigates in a billion-krona investment to strengthen its position in the Baltic Sea and signal readiness to defend its territory. Defence Minister Pål Jonson emphasises this purchase advances Sweden's strategic position against Russian military presence.

stories.headline: Teen deportations raise questions about Swedish values and family assessment
stories.summary: Concerns are growing about how Swedish authorities handle deportations of refugee children, with critics questioning current practices around family tie verification. The issue has sparked debate about whether procedures align with Swedish humanitarian principles.

stories.headline: Rising electricity prices push homeowners to optimise heating systems
stories.summary: Swedish households struggling with high electricity costs are finding solutions through system upgrades and optimisation. One homeowner has successfully reduced consumption and saved money by evaluating his heating setup — a strategy others can replicate.

stories.headline: AI job-filtering creates new challenges for Swedish job seekers
stories.summary: As artificial intelligence screens applications, job hunters need to understand how to avoid algorithmic filtering. Using relevant keywords and tailored applications are essential strategies in today's employment landscape.

stories.headline: Sexual harassment on Vinted prompts government action on digital platform safety
stories.summary: Young people selling secondhand clothes on the app Vinted have reported receiving sexual messages. Sweden's Minister for Gender Equality is now calling for stronger legal requirements on digital platforms to protect users from harassment.

stories.headline: Melodifestivalen third heat features strong contenders
stories.summary: Sweden's famous song competition continued its third round with performances from Medina and Saga Ludvigsson, who both advanced directly to the final. The competition showcased diverse musical styles and talent.
